instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H_CPU: What is PPBUS_G3H_CPU? PPBUS_G3H_CPU is the .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power Issue
threads.message:
Hi!

I would like to ask for assistance in a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board. I'm more like into iPhone repair but I had some success in older Macbook repairs. This is not a customer board, it is for me to entertain myself in this hard covid times...

I think I found a rabbit hole but I would like to ask for some guidance, and please be very clear and lucid with me, also with patience. Thank you.

HIstory: It is water damaged.
<CAPACITOR>C7748</CAPACITOR> was shorted so I removed it.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL> steady 13.05V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> steady 13.05V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 0V .170 in diode mode
<SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3S0</SIGNAL> 0V

From the power supply:
19.9V
0.04-0.06A
0.03-0.08A

Where should I look next?

Thank you for your time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power Issue
threads.message: Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS and correct RTC signals?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power Issue
threads.message:
Thank you for your answer.

I checked them and no luck, 0V on all of those.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power Issue
threads.message:
Any liquid sign around <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>?
Post diode mode to ground at L7670/90.
Also post <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> voltages; pins 23, 12, 13, 22, 29, 21.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power Issue
threads.message:
Hi!

Sign of liquid around <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>

L7670 is .416
L7690 is .001

pin12:0V
pin13:0V
pin21: 0V
pin22: 3.3V
pin23: around 0.5V
pin29: 0V

Edit:
Looks like the pin23 is damaged by corrosion. There is 13.05V on <CAPACITOR>C7650</CAPACITOR> capacitor.
Also the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> rail is shorted.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power Issue
threads.message:
"L7690 is .001"
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted to ground.
Lift L7690 one side and see where the short remains.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power Issue
threads.message:
Hi!

Short is on L7690 pin 1.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power Issue
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7650</CHIP> is still connect there.
If looks ugly, you can remove it and check again.
If short goes off, is yuor lucky day.
Be aware, do NOT power up the board without <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>, under any reason!!!

Is more probably to have the short in other point.
Ohm value is low enough to heat something injecting voltage.
Start with 1V and do not go higher than 4V.
Let PSU current limit to max and remove CPU heatsink.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power Issue
threads.message:
Hi!

I tried to locate the short but I can't find which one is. It is somewhere around <CAPACITOR>C8233</CAPACITOR> where the heat comes from. I tried to use the alcohol method and the thermal camera method but the whole area is heating up. Also the CPU is getting hot by the time because that is on the other side.

I checked and there is a short to ground on the <SIGNAL>PP1V_S5G</SIGNAL> as well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power Issue
threads.message:
Did you remove CPU heatsink?
Check if CPU die overheats.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power Issue
threads.message:
Hi!

CPU heatsink is removed. One of the dies I think is warmer than it supposed to be. CPU is dead?

Thank you for your answer.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power Issue
threads.message:
Central die is for CPU core, smaller one close to big coils is iGPU and the other is PCH.
Does PCH die overheats?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power Issue
threads.message:
Hi!

The PCH die is heating one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Power Issue
